That's quite a reach. I don't think so. Oddly, Clinton, about whom I've never been too enthusiastic, is looking better and better to me - just for the sheer strength and endurance she's demonstrated through all the witch hunts and mudslinging directed at her. Also strikes me that - in the same way many of the attacks on Obama were racially tinged, the relentless attacks on her have the whiff of misogyny. And I write this as someone who really dislikes identity politics. Just kind of unavoidable.
I hate to say it --- but these crooked guards deserve to loose their retirement funds and Seabrook deserves to rot in jail (and be confined so other corrupt guards don't have contact w him).

Of course proof of her faults have come up.
But you seem to have ignored them.
Yes, she absorbs the attacks, claims to have "misspoken" and moves on...
Of course she's smart and somewhat talented.
But I don't believe for a minute that she is ethically superior to Sanders.

Yes, she's such an iron-plated force of Nature, who's shrugged off everything thrown at her, that when a 74 year old man opened his mouth and uttered some completely reasonable criticisms, her supporters collapsed in convulsions of fear. What a joke.

My caution about Ms. Clinton has nothing to do with her gender - I too would say "It's about time a woman was President."    It's about her character.    I cannot shake the feeling that she has simply not been above-board as to her flaws in offices she has held or the moneyed people who have backed her.   I will vote for her because Trump is such a disaster waiting to happen to our world, but I will do so with little enthusiasm or conviction....if the Republicans had put up a reasonable candidate, I'd be voting Republican.   They have not, so I will not, but I'm not at all happy about backing Clinton.

Here is a woman who has faced 25 years -- TWENTY FIVE -- and more, of people lambasting her and attacking her, and what have they come up with for proof of supposed faults? Absolutely nothing. She has weathered it all, better than any public figure I know. And that she has done so as a woman in a deeply misogynist world is simply remarkable. Is she cautious? Is she centrist? Of course she is those things. If she were not cautious, or centrist, what would she be (called)? You know it: shrill, brazen, feminazi, etc etc. (which, come to think of it, she's been called anyway). She'll never please everybody, and she's smart enough to know that. So she absorbs these attacks and moves on. That's grit. That's smart.

So it's sad, still, to see people here -- even Dems -- attacking her still, using right-wing inspired talking points pedaled by FOX news and radio shock jocks. And let's not fool ourselves: the veneer of politesse is the thinnest facade hiding the distemper of those who simply cannot stand the idea that there are smart, talented women. I'll say this to them: smart, talented, Hilary Clinton will weather you too.

Eradicating the aedes aegypti mosquito in the USA with gene drive is a no brainer.  Get on with it and ignore the Pollyannas who fret about unintended consequences!  These anti science libs are the same folks who have been protesting GMO foods and contributing to world hunger.
Similar arguments could be used to delay the complete eradication of smallpox. However, I suspect that not many parents would prefer to eradicate their children, rather than smallpox.
Save the Farms, As a biologist you need to be aware that Aedes mosquitoes do not transmit malaria.  Several species of Anopheles mosquitoes transmit malaria.

There is a book out there, "Kudzu. The Weed That Ate The South. Back in the 1970s you could see this blanket of green leaves over miles and miles land along roadways. Millions of dollars were spent trying to control it. People made Kudzu Jelly and moonshiners made whiskey with it. It swallowed up trees and telephone poles (it was my job to find them along US 1) and any abandoned building. The only thing keeping it under control is developers cutting it back to build housing developments.
Add in Bamboo. It was brought in to suck up the water in the marshes. The water is gone mostly but the bamboo patches can be acres in size with some of it 6" in diameter and 15 foot tall.
African Violets. Brought into South Florida where I grew up to stop the erosion of the banks along waterways and canals. Now it clogs them up and has to be removed mechanically. The Manatees eat it but they aren't safe if they go into open water because of boaters.
And whose idea was it to bring in the 12" toads, Bufo marinus that squirts poison from glands on its back and the 12" snails in Dade County that are devouring all vegetation except Kudzu, Bamboo and African Violets?
We know who turns the Pythons loose in the Everglades. People who thought they were cute when they were small. Now they're 10 feet long and eating deer. Everything thrives in South Florida.
How about those Asian Carp in the Great Lakes?

I have one word for scientists considering gene editing: kudzu.

The list of things that seemed like a good idea at the time is too long. Quit repeating the same mistakes.

Can you imagine the decisions by the 1% if such selection were available? What?? are you kidding??? we are dead in our fruits of life, to these know it alls who say they know better. really - you need to mess with this too?
Just a clarification: Aedes spp. carry dengue, Zika, yellow fever etc; but only Anopheles spp. carry human malarias.

This is a new kind of pollution with incalculable consequences.
Evolution occurs over hundreds of millions of years with near
infinite iterations. To ignore this process, especially in the
context of complex ecosystems, is madness.

In West Africa, where the original Brer Rabbit stories originated, there is a wonderful legend of how the mosquito saved mankind. In the story, man was getting too big for his boots and the animals got together and asked God whether she could somehow constrain or eliminate the problem. The word went out that if 3 species would vouch for man in 2 weeks, he would be spared. Of course, dog immediately came forth and said that man fed and nurtured him. A week later, horse came and said that man looked after him. Time passed, and no other creature came forth until finally, within hours of the deadline, mosquito came forth … and that is how mosquito saved humanity. The story always makes me laugh if only for testimony of the very human ability to make the best of a bad situation.
Having said, are we not also like a virus spreading without limit, consuming all earth’s resources recklessly without constraint? Maybe the animals who requested the initial divine intervention had a point, but perhaps more ominously, this technology could eventually be used against a humanity that refuses to acknowledge its own overpopulated destiny.

Very very easy for all the smart people living in the comfortable air conditioned screened in USA to sit on their sofa with their smart phone and pontificate .  Maybe if you had a relative or a child who died of Malaria living in a country without air conditioning, without sanitation or sewers, beset by the consequences of the American century of mass carbon pollution you might see it differently. Once the Earth's temperature rises a little more and Zika has firmly set root in the US and the microcephalic children are counted in the thousands, excessively worried technophobes attitudes will change towards this potentially misery reducing technology.  Until then, try not to watch Jurassic Park.

With respect to judging the potential unintended consequences of releasing this gene drive system into the wild, it is important to take into account the fact that CRISPR is already a ubiquitous bacterial genetic defense mechanism. In other words, using the gene drive isn't going to unleash an alien genetic mechanism into a susceptible environment with the potential to be hijacked into a monster; these genes are already in the environment.

whatever your choice is, it is still a guess.  doing nothing is just as big a guess as  modifying.  all it would take is a virus that results in permanent sterility in humans and the countdown to extinction is on.

Two thoughts come to mind.

First, while modifying the DNA of organisms is becoming routine, getting those modifications to perform well is typically challenging. In that respect it’s rather ‘arrogant’ to think a gene drive experiment is going work ‘better’ than anticipated and decimate the target species, much less jump to and decimate a non-target species.

Second, while people fret about genetic modification - where after more than two decades of activity documented evidence of harm is minor or non-existent - we seem to give no more than a shrug to damage wrought by invasive species, which the Nature Conservancy estimates at 120 billion dollars annually http://www.nature.org/ourinitiatives/habitats/forests/explore/invasives-... or to the tens of thousands of deaths each year caused by our favorite mode of transportation.
People fear what they don't understand and also don't understand the underlying problem for why this technology was adapted to this problem in the first place.
An idealistic past that never existed in the first place - because we conveniently forget the diseases and other afflictions of past generations that we now control as a matter of routine.
And we'd only need to get rid of a very small number of the many mosquito species that exist. There'd still be plenty of others left to slap and cuss at.
Anti GM logic at its finest...

Humans already are shaping evolution on this planet. We have been doing this for millennia. We are now just getting more sophisticated.
Overall, this is just one other aspect of evolution. The biggest "gene drive", though, is climate change. That affects many species at the same time with less predictable results. (I am aware that this is not a perfect analogy)
Besides, let's not get ahead of ourselves. Nature will find a way around this again. It is called 'resistance'. Let's not overestimate our own cleverness just yet. In the end, biology and nature will win - again.

You can do your part. Stop taking any medications that are derived from scientific research including aspirin.  You may also want to show the world the righteousness of your views by foregoing anesthetic during your visit the dentist or in surgery.

I'm not anti-science...have a PhD in theoretical physics myself. But when people are sufficiently frightened the good and the bad get jumbled together.

Gene editing is scary. It WILL misfire. The only question is how long that'l take.

Then what?

Finally with gene drive we have the means to generate profound hatred for science and scientists.

Maybe it's time...

We need really good clean up crews ready to mitigate the consequences of all our advancements: perpetual nuclear waste storage after the fact of nuclear 'power' and weapons; mountaintop restoration after the fact of mountaintop 'removal'; mixed forest regeneration after the fact of 'clear cutting'; water purification after the fact of polluting with poisons and wastes that should have never gone there in the first place.

We just take all the best and leave the mess for the grandkids. They won't thank us...
